ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CLOB SHARES


    1. Mr Heng Chiang Meng asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether the equivalent volume of $229 billion worth of Malaysian equities traded on CLOB International quoted in a Malaysian White Paper will go to the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange now that there is no CLOB International and whether there will be greater liquidity for Singapore equities traded on the Stock Exchange of Singapore in the absence of CLOB International.

    2. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether he will give an update on the status of negotiations with the Malaysian government on the US$2.6 billion worth of frozen Central Limit Order Book (CLOB) shares.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I will take the first two Questions together.

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Heng Chiang Meng has asked whether past investor interest in Clob Malaysian shares would now go to the KL Stock Exchange, since Malaysian shares are no longer traded on Clob; or whether this investor interest will migrate to the SES.

    Retail investors actively traded Clob Malaysian shares for two main reasons. Firstly, historically close ties between the two countries gave Singapore retail investors a keen interest in Malaysian companies. They wanted to invest in Malaysian companies even after the KLSE and the SES parted ways in 1973 and Malaysian counters were delisted from the SES in 1990. And secondly, Clob made it much more convenient for Singapore investors to buy Malaysian shares. Investors here could transact in S$ without being exposed to foreign currency risk; and they could deal through Singapore brokers, with whom they were more familiar. This was why Clob was successful.

Column: 1545



    Since the cessation of the trading of Malaysian shares on Clob in September 1998, retail investor interest has shifted to Singapore shares listed on the SES. This can be seen from the increase in the turnover on SES. From October 1998 to March 1999, SES recorded an average monthly turnover of S$9.8 billion. This figure, without Clob trading, is 63% higher than the average of S$6.0 billion per month transacted in the same shares during the 8-month period (from January 1998 to August 1998) before Clob ceased trading in Malaysian counters. The main reason is loss of convenience with the closure of Clob and the imposition of capital controls in Malaysia.

    It therefore appears that investors on Clob have for now shifted their interest from Malaysian to Singapore shares.

    There have been accusations that Clob investors shorted Malaysian shares, and were responsible for the collapse of the Malaysian stock market. But very few institutions invested in Malaysian shares through Clob. SES figures confirm that an overwhelming majority of Clob investors (in fact more than 98%) were individuals rather than institutional investors.

    A recent comprehensive analysis by the Singapore Business Times, based on data obtained from SES, conclusively refuted the charge that Clob caused the decline in the KL Stock Exchange. I have circulated the full BT analysis to Members. You can find it on your seats.

    BT found no evidence of significant short-selling on Clob. Judging by share buy-ins by SES, short-selling of Clob shares had been negligible. BT also analysed trading data on the three days each year which showed the largest falls in the KLCI, for the last five years. It found few Clob counters among the top 30 losing stocks on those days. Further, turnover in these Clob counters was much lower than the corresponding turnover

Column: 1546

on the KLSE - generally less than 5% of KLSE turnover for the same counters. This is hardly the picture of rampant short-selling on Clob.

    BT studied more closely the period from the end of 1996, before the Asian crisis, up to 31st August 1998, just before Malaysia imposed capital controls. Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I will ask the Clerk to distribute a chart showing how the KL stock index as well as Clob investors' shareholdings move during this period. [Copies of chart (Cols. 1665-1666) distributed to hon. Members.] Members will see from the chart that over this period Clob holdings of Malaysian shares rose steadily, even as the KL Composite Index declined continuously and steeply together with other regional stock indices. The KLCI lost three quarters of its value, falling from 1,238 on 31st December 1996 to 302 by 31st August 1998. But Clob investors doubled their holdings of Malaysian shares, from 5.7 billion on 31st December 1996 to 11.7 billion on 31st August 1998. This is counting the total number of shares. Their holdings increased steadily quarter by quarter, despite the decline of the KLCI and the deepening economic crisis in the region and in Malaysia. The sell-down of Malaysian shares did not take place in Singapore.
chart - KLSE Composite Index and Clob Investors' Shareholdings of Malaysian Shares (Dec 96 - Aug 98) (Cols. 1665-1666)


    Despite the recent rally in the Malaysian market, at today's prices many Clob investors are sitting on losses. Whether they decide to sell, hold or buy more shares on the Malaysian stock market once their trading accounts are opened will depend on their assessment of the value of their shares and of the rules governing their trades.

Update on the Clob Issue

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan has asked for an update on the frozen Clob shares. I last briefed Parliament on the status of Clob shares during the Committee of Supply in March this year. Yesterday, SES issued a press statement setting out the events leading to the signing of the Agreement,

Column: 1547

and the background to the cash offer by Effective Capital Sdn Bhd to buy over Clob shares from investors. I have circulated copies of the SES statement to Members.

    Members will recall that SES' Central Depository Pte Ltd (CDP) signed an agreement in September last year with the Malaysian Securities Clearing Automated Network Services Sdn Bhd (SCANS), a subsidiary of KLSE. The agreement provided for the migration of all Clob shares to investors' own securities accounts with the Malaysian Central Depository (MCD), based on procedures determined and announced by the KLSE. As the SES statement explained, the SES and CDP have done what is expected of them under the Agreement. But till today SCANS has not fulfilled its part of the agreement, which would enable Clob investors to have their shares in their own securities accounts and to trade their shares on the KLSE.

    In the meantime, certain "private sector" solutions have been proposed. One is by Mr Akbar Khan, a Singaporean businessman resident in Malaysia. He has formed a company, Effective Capital Sdn Bhd, which on 30th April 1999 offered to buy Clob shares from investors for cash. The prices offered are on average 58% lower than the prices quoted on the KLSE as at 30th April.

    There have also been media reports of other possible offers, including an offer to Clob investors of shares in a closed-end investment fund, to be listed on the KLSE, and which will gradually divest the shares.

    The SES statement yesterday gave details of its discussions with Mr Khan on his offer. This was to inform Clob investors of the background to Mr Khan's proposal, and of SES' discussions with Mr Khan and his Singapore lawyer, Mr Sat Pal Khattar of Khattar Wong and Partners.

    The SES has maintained throughout that "private sector" offers by Mr Khan or any other party cannot and do not affect CDP's Agreement with SCANS. This is the advice of SES' lawyers, who have also consulted Queen's Counsel on the offer.

Column: 1548

The lawyers have also advised the SES that Clob investors were, and remain, legal owners of their shares. The Agreement signed by SCANS recognises that Clob shares have the same legal rights as the same classes of shares listed on the KLSE, and gives full effect to these legal rights. Indeed Clob shares have continued to receive dividends and offers for rights issues.

    The SES has therefore insisted on clear and reasonable arrangements being made for Clob investors who do not accept any private offers. They should have their shares transferred to their own accounts with the MCD and be allowed to trade them on the KLSE.

    Mr Khan's offer, which is a cash offer for Malaysian securities, does not need to comply with regulatory requirements in Singapore. However, in view of the considerable public interest, the SES has pointed out where the offer documents fall short of generally accepted international standards.

    SES' lawyers have advised that the CDP has a duty to disseminate details of any offers made to Clob investors, and convey acceptances of the offers to the offerors. CDP will carry out this obligation to inform Clob investors and collect their responses to Mr Khan's offer. In so doing, neither SES nor CDP will be sponsoring, sanctioning or making any recommendation to Clob investors as to whether to accept or reject the offer.

    Clob investors should carefully study the offer by Mr Khan, before deciding for themselves whether to take it up. They should consider all relevant factors, including the prices that Effective Capital has offered for their shares.

    Clob investors who do not wish to sell their shares on the terms offered by Mr Khan, or to accept any other subsequent offers, do not have to do so. Their legal ownership of their Clob shares is not in issue.

    The SES will continue to press the KLSE and SCANS to meet their obligations

Column: 1549

under the migration Agreement. As the SES has stated, the respective obligations of the two parties are not matters of opinion, but a legal question which can be determined. SES has obtained legal advice that the agreement is a legally binding and enforceable contract.

    The Government has also taken up the Clob issue with the Malaysian Government at the political level. Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong discussed the Clob issue with Prime Minister Dr Mahathir at a bilateral meeting in Hanoi in December last year. Both PM Goh and Dr Mahathir subsequently told the press that Clob would be included in the package of outstanding bilateral issues to be discussed and resolved by the two Governments. Dr Mahathir said at a press conference in Hanoi on 17th December 1998, and I quote: "I thought that it is best that we resolve as a package, including of course the problem of CPF and Clob." Dr Mahathir also said, and again I quote: "We would rather like to settle the whole thing as a package so that the water supply is linked to the problem of the railway, CIQ, CLOB and CPF".

    However, the Malaysian Government subsequently changed its stand. On 13th March 1999, Reuters quoted Malaysian Finance Minister Tun Daim Zainuddin saying that discussions between Singapore and Malaysia on the Clob issue should be left to the KLSE and SES, and were not part of the overall "package" of issues to be discussed at the government level. Reuters quoted Tun Daim: "I've always maintained it's between KLSE and SES. . As far as I know, it is not part of the package; if they want to include it in the package, it is up to the parties, both governments."

    Malaysian and Singaporean senior officials have met twice this year on 11th March and on 21st and 22nd April to discuss the proposed package deal. At both meetings, the Malaysian delegation asked that Clob be removed from the agenda as it was not a Government-to-Government issue. Singapore's response

Column: 1550

on both occasions was that the Clob issue should not remain outstanding when the package is finally resolved. This remains Singapore's stand.

    The Government and SES will make every effort to resolve the Clob issue expeditiously. Clob investors have provided support for Malaysian shares over the years, even when the market was declining over the two years before the imposition of capital controls. It is not to anyone's advantage for Clob investors to feel that they are being treated unfairly, or for the international markets to perceive so.

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San): Sir, I have a number of supplementary questions for the Deputy Prime Minister. (1) May I ask the Deputy Prime Minister, since the statistics from Clob show a diametrically opposite picture from that in the Malaysian White Paper, whether SES or even the Government would inform the Malaysian government of these statistics through normal channels? (2) May I also ask the Deputy Prime Minister whether the issue of frozen Clob Malaysian shares could be brought up to international organisations such as WTO or even the International Court of Justice for resolution since it was clear that the trading of Malaysian shares on Clob was all along completely legal and the freeze was because the MCD had changed its rules regarding nominee shareholdings on 31st August 1998, coupled with SCANS not fulfilling its legal obligation of transferring the shares to individual accounts with MCD? (3) I would also like to ask him why CDP, as the umbrella nominee holder for Clob Malaysian shares, has not taken any legal action on this issue so far? (4) Since any private sector party is not precluded from making an offer for Clob Malaysian shares, could an organisation such as GIC or Temasek make an offer to purchase the shares at reasonable prices? In this respect, why is SES even considering the offer from an individual such as Mr Akbar Khan? Who is he? Does this mean that any future offers for Clob shares by any individual, regardless of the background or standing, will also receive the same consideration from the Stock Exchange of Singapore?

Column: 1551



    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, we will of course extend copies of the analysis from the Business Times as well as the statistics I have given to Members today and the graph to the Malaysian authorities. We hope they would be helpful to them when studying the problem.

    As for bringing the matter to the World Trade Organisation or the International Court of Justice, this is not a matter in the purview of the WTO, nor is it a treaty between the two countries, because the agreement was signed between SCANS on the Malaysian side and CDP on the Singapore side. But as I have informed Members, we are taking legal advice, including advice from QC, on our rights in this matter. That also answers the question on legal action. We are taking advice on our rights.

    Could GIC or Temasek offer to buy? Mr Speaker, Sir, I think that would be very dangerous. Individual investors invested on Clob on their own. This was over the counter. These were not shares which were listed on the Singapore Stock Exchange. They were shares listed elsewhere and not subject to our disclosure rules or corporate governance standards. Investors went in hoping to make a good return. There was no arrangement that if they made a good return, the Government would collect a small percentage, and if they went down, the Government would bear some of the loss. So for the Government to go in with GIC or Temasek to offer to buy these shares from Singaporeans, I think, would be a very, very dangerous precedent. The whole idea that individuals must take responsibility for their investment and must consider carefully and decide and take the rough and the smooth is there. What the Government can do in this circumstance, which has arisen, is to take up with the Malaysian authorities to try and get the matter resolved and that, as I have explained to Members, we are in the process of doing.

    Why does the SES consider Mr Akbar Khan's offer? Mr Speaker, Sir, the short answer is that we have reason to believe, and we satisfied ourselves, that Mr Akbar

Column: 1552

Khan was acting with the endorsement of the Malaysian authorities.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have two supplementary questions for the DPM. Firstly, I see that we cannot go to WTO. But could we explore the possibility of arbitration in a third country? Secondly, would SES demand, and I use the word "demand", MCD to comply with the agreement reached on 18th September between SES and KLSE SCANS on the question of migration of Clob shares, especially as the Clob shares have been transferred to an omnibus account?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, we will explore all possibilities and take QC's advice as to what our rights are and how they can be given effect. The QC's advice is that this is a legally binding enforceable agreement and that, in fact, we are entitled to specific performance from the other party. How to get that done, whether arbitration or not, these are matters which I leave to the lawyers.

    As for demanding that MCD complies, indeed that is what we have been raising with MCD. It is not a matter of raising our voices. It is a matter of getting rights recognised.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): The graph which the Deputy Prime Minister has provided shows conclusively that there was no dumping of Malaysian shares on Clob. I presume it is the volume of shares. I have two questions in order to make the picture complete. The first question is the volume of shares that he has provided on this graph. What is the percentage of this volume compared to the volume of those respective shares on the KLSE? Is it a large volume? Or is it a small volume? Can significant movements on the Clob really affect Malaysian stock prices that much? The second question I have is that the graph and the details which have been provided here show, for example, the increase in the volume of Clob shares. What about the statistics on short selling as such? Are there any statistics on the volume and value of short selling?

Column: 1553



    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not have the figures on what percentage the Clob shares accounted for the corresponding total number of shares in these companies. I believe it would be small, probably around a quarter. But I am hazarding a guess. Most of the trading with Malaysia and KL and nearly all of the institutional investors, who are the big players, invested in KL rather than in Clob. Clob was providing a facility for Singaporean investors.

    As for the volume of short selling, as I said in my reply, it was small. We do not have direct numbers for this. What we have are the figures for share buy-ins because when somebody is short and unable to recover his position by the time the delivery is due, then the Exchange will go in and buy-in on his behalf in order to meet his obligations. The volume of buy-ins on Clob has been very low and, therefore, we believe that the volume of shorting has been very low. The fact is that overall, Clob shareholders have increased their total holding of shares. Each time, the stock market fell, they bought into a falling market. Over two years, it shows that overall, they were not dumping Malaysian shares. They were investing in Malaysian shares and they doubled their holdings in two years.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): It seems that from this incident, Singaporeans are being singled out and treated differently from other investors in other countries. I have two questions. Firstly, are there any other investments other than the Clob shares that have been affected by the controls that the Malaysian government has placed specifically for Singaporeans? For example, I recall that we have some ringgit holdings. What has happened to them? Secondly, is there any message from the Government to Singaporeans regarding investing in the Malaysian market in the future? Even if he invests directly in the KLSE today, will he be treated differently again in the future?

    BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, other investments in Malaysia would of course be affected by the capital controls,

Column: 1554

in terms of movements of float funds and withdrawal of funds.

    As for the ringgit holdings, I do not have the latest position. But I understand that they have been converted into commercial deposits and have gradually been withdrawn over a period of time in a way which has not caused a disturbance in the market, and which the Malaysian authorities were aware of.

    As to whether other investments in Malaysia now will be affected by future uncertainties, I am in no position to answer that question.

Column: 1554

INTERNET
(Blocking access to web-sites of satanic cults)



    3. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for Information and the Arts if his Ministry will consider blocking access to the web-sites of satanic cults on the Internet because they pose enormous potential harm to our young and the unwitting public.

    The Minister for Information and the Arts (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): The Internet has a large number of esoteric sites which cover subjects ranging from UFOs to Satanic cults. MITA and MHA monitor some of these sites like "Temple of the Beast".

    These sites vary a great deal. Most have no mass impact at all. But should they denigrate religious beliefs, threaten religious harmony or incite hatred, we will take action to remove them. The Singapore Broadcasting Authority will work with the ISPs to block out sites that are clearly unsuitable for the young in the Family Access Network.

    Singaporeans should refer dangerous sites to the SBA if they come across them. If such sites are created locally and break our laws, the relevant agencies will take action against the content creators in accordance with the law.

SINGAPORE 21
(Motion)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question (4th May, 1999),

    "That this House endorses the Vision for Singapore in the 21st century as set out in the report of the Singapore 21 Committee "Singapore 21: Together, We Make The Difference", contained in Paper Misc. 2 of 1999, as the basis for strengthening the heartware of Singapore and meeting the aspirations of Singaporeans.". - [Minister for Education].

    Question again proposed.
12.55 pm

    Mr Cyrille Tan (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to commend the Minister and his team for an excellent S21 Report. Many Members of this House have debated extensively on the Report. I will focus my speech on the "Opportunities for All".

    Sir, in the Report on "Opportunities for All", it was mentioned that as a society Singaporeans must give a second chance to those who want to try again, and Singaporeans of all ages will always have opportunities to upgrade and renew their knowledge and skills.

    The NTUC has always subscribed to this principle. Through various schemes, we have been encouraging our workers to upgrade their skills and be relevant to the workplace and society. Examples are the Skills Redevelopment Programme (SRP), the NTUC-Education and Training Fund and other funding schemes. Many workers have taken opportunities available to them and have benefited from the various schemes, getting for themselves trade certificates that are recognised nationwide.

    However, while the NTUC, together with the Government, is stressing the need to give the lower income Singaporeans a second chance, there are still many cases of older Singaporeans who have been denied such chances when it comes to a crunch. Age seems to be the main determining factor of entry into many companies, for example, those from the wafer fabrication and semi-conductor industries.

Column: 1556



    Regardless of how skilful, flexible and adaptable an elderly Singaporean may be, he may still have very little opportunities in contributing in such companies. Many recruiting companies have specifically asked for younger workers, even though there are older workers with relevant skills. As a result, such good paying jobs go mainly to the younger job seekers. We must not forget that our older workers are willing and ready to try again.

    I would like to give a scenario which is very common in Singapore, particularly now when restructuring exercises are conducted by companies adversely affected by the recent economic downturn. A skilled worker in the electronics industry was retrenched at the age of 45. Probably, he is the sole breadwinner of the family. He has the necessary skills and even the certificates. However, in job fairs conducted by recruiting companies, he is told, although he has what it takes to fit into some of the recruiting companies, that they are looking for young individuals who are below the age of 40. Sad, but true, that mid-career workers who are retrenched are facing such problems. Does it mean that if I am a skilled worker, but over 40 years old, and retrenched, I will have to settle for a low-paying cleaner's job, a packer's job, something that will not tap into the knowledge and skills that I had acquired over my 20 years of working life?

    We are facing a growing pool of older workers, and we, as a nation, must not see that as a problem, but to capitalise on it as an opportunity. Such older workers have a wealth of knowledge and skills that the nation can tap on, instead of facing premature redundancy in society. Statistics show that in the electronics industry, 61.2% of those still looking for a job said that they cannot meet with the minimum age requirement set by recruiting companies.

    Singapore must remain committed to developing the full potentials of its citizens, as stated in the report on "Opportunities for All". I think it is time for us to examine the next step. And after realising the potentials of our citizens, through

Column: 1557

training and upgrading, how can Singapore, as a nation, make use of these human resources to further push the country another step ahead?

    Finally, Sir, human resource personnel should not be allowed to make a mockery of our plans for life-long learning.

    Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Goh Choon Kang (Marine Parade)(In Mandarin): Sir, before I go into the subject matter of this debate, let me take this opportunity to give my response on the issue of SAP schools. This issue has been discussed on many occasions. However, I think the more important thing is whether or not we could have a feasible policy. Some people suggested that the SAP schools and the other schools could become sister schools where some common activities can be carried out. However, I feel that even if it is done in this way, some people will still feel that it is not enough. In my view, a more direct method would be like what Senior Minister proposed not long ago, that is, to allow some top students from the minority groups to study in the SAP schools, that is to say, to break through the present situation in which only Chinese students are studying in the SAP schools.

    I support such a proposal because this would eliminate some of the doubts which people have on the SAP schools. By so doing, we would allow the top students from the various ethnic groups more options to study in a number of top schools other than the handful of traditional "branded" schools such as the Raffles Institution, etc. This would not affect the original mission of the SAP school.s. It is a positive development. It is an enlargement of the roles of the SAP schools. As in the days of the old Nanyang University (Nantah) which also had the Malay Studies Department, it did not affect the characteristics of Nantah at that time. So I feel SAP schools today would be willing to accept this proposal and this is perhaps the time for the minority ethnic

Column: 1558

groups to indicate their willingness to participate in such a proposal.

    Now, I would like to speak on the Singapore 21 report and to give my personal views on it. We can be said to be at the threshold of the 21st century. As we are stepping into the 21st century, this Singapore 21 report has highlighted two major dilemmas that we will be facing. First, the dilemma inherent in our social structure and the other is the dilemma that will come with our globalisation effort to develop Singapore into a cosmopolitan city. However, both these dilemmas concern one very basic question, that is, how to enhance our social and national cohesion and to reduce the centrifugal force.

    Yesterday, Prime Minister Goh mentioned the basic conflict in our social structure, that is, the tension or perhaps we could say the pulling force in our multi-racial society. This is an inherent conflict. Secondly, while we are globalising and developing Singapore into a global city, on the one hand, we have to encourage our people to venture overseas and, on the other hand, we spare no efforts to attract foreign talents to come here. This has actually created a conflict between the centrifugal force and centripetal force. To the bona fide Singaporeans, those who were born and bred here, they have a very special passion for Singapore. This was stated in a sentence from the poem entitled Ascending the Tower by the famous poet of the Tang Dynasty, " ", Wang Chan, which translated loosely means, whether a person is doing well or not, he would have a special emotional feeling for the land on which he was born and bred. Therefore, we can see that many of our Singaporeans who were posted overseas would become very homesick during the festive seasons. They would miss the dear ones in Singapore, and also from time to time, they will miss the food we have in our hawker centres in Singapore. How do we enhance this feeling of Singaporeans so that they can feel passionately about Singapore, even when they are overseas?

Column: 1559



    Apart from the very naturally nurtured feelings for those who were born and bred in Singapore, I feel that the most important thing is that we have to make everyone feel that he loves his country and the country loves him. Everyone should feel that he has a share in this country. On the national level, we have this Home Ownership Scheme. That is a very good example of how to make everybody feel that he has a share in this nation. National service has also reminded every citizen that he has a share in this nation and that is why we say everyone has a responsibility in the destiny of the country.

    In order to enhance our people's sense of belonging and ownership, I feel that the Government should enlarge this policy to reach to the people, particularly in the business sector. We should encourage more companies to have this "Employee Shares Ownership" scheme, that is to say, let the employees own shares in the company they work for. Nowadays, some companies are already implementing this system. Every employee, irrespective of the position in that company, would have some shares in the company. So they are both employees and shareholders of the company. This would naturally give them a stronger sense of belonging for the company. If this company has only a small minority of senior officers owning shares in the company while the vast majority of the employees have none, and you want these employees to develop a sense of belonging to the company, I think this would be a very difficult task.

    It is like an army going to war, and after the war, all the credits go to the general, and his soldiers who risked their lives fighting in the frontline were given no recognition at all. How are we going to cultivate in them a sense of belonging, and I am sure that the morale will be very low too. However, to make a person cultivate his sense of belonging to his country, I think it concerns not only the materialistic aspect. Spiritual and cultural factors are equally important. In this aspect, I must emphasise the importance of a cultural sense of identity. As a multi-racial society, we must pay particular

Column: 1560

attention to the sense of cultural belonging of the various races, that is, to allow all the communities to feel comfortable in their own cultural environment. Just as what Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said in this House yesterday, Singapore is not a nation yet. Therefore, we have to work harder in forging a national identity to promote better unity among the various races and to establish in them a sense of loyalty towards our nation.

    However, while we are seeking a common identity, we should also allow diversities to exist. We should allow the various races to preserve their own cultural traditions. This is, in fact, our current policy. Culture is the spiritual pillar of the individuals. That a person has a strong passion for his country, to a large extent, is due to the foundation of his cultural identity. A cultural sense of belonging would enhance his feelings and passion for the land on which he lives. Any differences in the various cultures would undermine our unity and it is something that we could not completely eliminate.

    What we should do is to try and forge better consensus and to have a better sense of belonging. What I want to say is that the policy which is implemented by our Government, that is, obtaining consensus while maintaining diversity, is a correct policy. When we are moving towards the 21st century, we should try and strengthen this policy and not to weaken it. It is not feasible to try and have a homogenous society because each race and community will treasure and defend its existing culture, habits, traditions, customs, language and religious beliefs. To the Chinese community, which is the majority here, or the minorities such as the Malays or Indians, it is the same. For example, our Malay brothers have this saying, biar mati anak, jangan mati adat. Cultural tradition is actually the soul of the tribes, or we could call it the tribal soul. They value this tribal soul more than their children. Multi-culturalism is actually an important component part of the Singapore heartware.

Column: 1561



    I feel that in our multi-cultural social environment, this is also a very important factor to attract foreign talents. Because I discover that many permanent residents or new citizens from other countries who come and settle down in Singapore actually do not come directly from their native countries. Many of them have actually gone to countries which they believed to be ideal societies such as the United States of America or Europe. After staying there for some time, they came to Singapore and eventually decided to settle down permanently in Singapore. Why? It is because of this multi-cultural environment which makes them feel very comfortable and at home.

    In some of the activities or gatherings organised by the Residents' Committees and at the new citizens' oath-taking ceremony organised by the Immigration Department, I would normally take the opportunity to ask these new citizens why they have decided to migrate to Singapore. Generally, they will tell me that they perceive that in Singapore they would receive equal treatment and equal opportunity. Most of them are bilingual in their mother tongue as well as English. In our multi-cultural environment, they feel at home and very comfortable. It is very easy for them to merge into our society here. On the other hand, in other countries, they may be able to earn a living, but they could not help having this feeling of being second-class citizens. This type of personal experience was mentioned by Dr Lee Tsao Yuan yesterday.

    On 3rd May 1999, there was a report by the Straits Times entitled "Racial Tone to US Handling of Spy Story". In this article, it mentioned that just because of one isolated incident where a Chinese scientist was alleged to have stolen their secret and passed it to China, now everyone in the United States is saying that all the Asian migrants, particularly the Chinese in the US and those who have obtained US citizenship, are spies from China and their loyalty for the United States is in doubt. I believe that many foreign talents would

Column: 1562

come to Singapore from the United States or the European countries not without a reason.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, on our present policy of forging an identity while maintaining diversity, I must reiterate that this is a correct policy. When we are moving towards the 21st century, what we need to do is to strengthen this policy. However, we cannot deny that, as I said just now, every race and every nationality would have its own identity, and there is a certain conflict between the existing "tribal soul" and the "national soul" that we want to establish. As we cannot use a pressure cooker or a big melting pot to melt all the races into one, the conflict between the tribal soul and the national soul would take a long time to be amalgamated. What we need to do is to maintain the present situation of harmonious living among our races. We have to enhance the communication, mutual understanding and unity among the various races. That is to say, our present policy must be maintained and sustained.

    In this respect, I feel that we need to have a very strong Government to maintain such a pluralistic policy. In our present situation of harmonious living among the races, to a large extent, credit must be given to our strong Government in giving equal treatment to all the various races, and to protect the interests of the minority groups. In the past few decades, the Government has been hitting hard at the racists and tried its best to eliminate the conflicts among the races to reduce the centrifugal force and to enhance the centripetal force to promote unity among the various races. We have emphasised participation of all citizens. In such a complicated social structure like ours, we need to have nothing short of a strong Government. Whether it is in the family or in a company, we need to have very fair and strong parents and management to avoid confusion. I think it is the same for a country.

    Sir, while we are moving into the 21st century, we need to have a consensus. I believe the Singapore 21 Committee led by RAdm Teo held various discussion

Column: 1563

panels and dialogue sessions and in the process, the consensus has been forged. This is definitely of great help to the enhancement of the Singapore heartware and definitely beneficial to our development in the next century.

    Sir, I support the motion.

    The Minister without Portfolio (Mr Lim Boon Heng): Mr Speaker, Sir, a Straits Times journalist, after hearing the Prime Minister yesterday, wrote in her column this morning: "why the sobering message?" She reflected not only her views but those of some of her colleagues as well. This, after what I thought was a very clear message from the Prime Minister, supplemented by personal accounts from other Members, that our society is one with many fault lines. These fault lines are fundamentals as we continue with nation building.

    The journalist said that the Prime Minister did not give examples to explain why he delivered his sobering message. Yet, I thought he gave many, from other parts of the world, to remind us that our fault lines can give way as disastrously. At least one Member, Mr Zainul Abidin, gave the example of Malays in the SAF as one indicator of our fault lines.

    Sir, is there a gap between those above 50 years of age, and those a generation younger in their 30s? Have we so succeeded in blurring ethnic lines that the younger generation already accepts race as a non-issue? As a Backbencher in the 80s, I attended several clan functions. For one who is English-educated, it meant hard work preparing to speak in Mandarin, and there was always not enough time. There was only one Lim in the Backbench, me. How I wished there were more, so that the load could be shared. At one of these functions, I said I wished there were more Lims in Parliament. I did not get to finish my sentence to express my sentiment, because I was drowned out by the applause! All I could do after that was to meekly say that I wished in future there would be more Lims. And, again, big applause. So, it taught me that whilst we have enshrined equality of race, language

Column: 1564

and religion as the cornerstone of our nation, we disregard the fault lines at our peril.

    Then, last year, as part of our May Day celebrations, we put up a live TV programme. As we did not have the money to put up separate programmes in the four languages, we insisted that TCS 8 agree that we have items in English, Tamil and Malay, in addition to Chinese. Of course, everybody knows that TCS 8 is a Chinese channel. We thought we were being sensitive to the minority races in making sure that it was a multi-lingual programme, but we got a very negative reaction from a Berita Harian journalist!

    If we need a more recent example to remind us, it is the emotion with which Members spoke in this House on the subject of SAP schools and the nurturing of a Chinese elite. If we use the Prime Minister's imagery of the four interlocking circles, the emotions raised over SAP schools pose us a very pertinent question: How much non-overlapping space will each circle allow the others?

    We should all be very pleased if the primordial forces the Prime Minister referred to have mutated to benign forms, like spent volcanoes. But the Prime Minister reminded us very clearly yesterday that dormant volcanoes can erupt, and with great force. This is why we must set realistic expectations about Singapore 21. We must start with the correct assessment of what we are, and build from here.

    Singapore 21 is about building a nation with hearts that beat as one. It means citizens feeling they belong here so deeply they will defend it. It is about developing roots, a thick web of roots, so that the tree will stand even when the storm is fierce. What does this mean in practical terms? Our roots are our families, our friends, the networks we form through churches, mosques or temples, the networks we form through other community organisations, and the bonds we develop through friendship struck in school. It is also about getting Singaporeans to feel they too have created a piece of Singapore.

Column: 1565



    Sir, by any account, the S21 Committee has reached out to a very large number of Singaporeans. Yes, the Committee practised "consultation" and distilled what 6,000 Singaporeans have contributed into one document. But there will be the balance of the 3.1 million Singaporeans, who are not among the 6,000, who will feel that they have not been consulted. Indeed, Mr Chiam reflected this the day before yesterday, when he said his party had no part in it!

    There will be some among the 6,000 who are left dissatisfied because their pet ideas are not included in the final document.

    There will be expectations of greater consultation as part of public policy formulation. So we have to understand what is possible, and what is not. Those of us who work in the trade unions engage union leaders and workers in numerous dialogue sessions, as many as our diaries would permit us. Yet we cannot avoid the comment from time to time from some union leaders that there was a lack of consultation! So let us be quite clear that consultation does not mean every citizen is to be consulted, and that every point each citizen brings up will be included, because it is impossible.

    Yet every citizen wants to participate and feel part of Singapore. But participation does not only mean being directly consulted. Participation also means doing things ourselves, for our benefit, and for society. I think this is far more important. We have to create that sense among Singaporeans that they play a part actively in our society. Never mind what priorities Government may have, so long as we are able to contribute what we think is meaningful to ourselves.

    There is a group of Singaporeans who participate in this way, through community groups and voluntary welfare organisations. They go beyond discussing issues and expecting Government to do something about it, to make things

Column: 1566

happen themselves. And they do not wait to be invited.

    If we want something done, will we shake out of our inertia, and do something about it? The older generation of Singaporeans had no choice but to do things for themselves, be it to set up funds for the needy, or to build schools. If a poorer educated group of Singaporeans could do so, there is absolutely no reason why a better educated group now cannot.

    It all depends on whether we are prepared to make the effort. Sir, let me cite a simple example. You might even regard it as trivial. 26 of my primary one classmates meet once a year, with our form teacher. We are a real mixed group of people - workers, shopkeepers and one politician! How did it happen? Was it started by the school principal, or by the teacher? No, we were brought together by three close friends from the class. They had met regularly every Sunday since they left school. One day one of them thought it would be a good idea to organise a class get-together. So from the names in an old school magazine, they set about contacting the class. They called up people with the same name in the telephone directory, sometimes getting scolded for their trouble! There are more than one person with the same name, and those with the name "Lim Boon Heng" in the directory are not mine. The three of them did not wait for others to act. They took the initiative, and even now each year, they organise the get-together. So my point is, if we feel strongly about something and are prepared to do it, we can, and we can make a difference, and we enjoy doing the things that matter to us.

    Sir, I said developing roots also mean the bonds we develop through school. Here, I believe that there are considerable merits in the old school system, when a child can study from primary one right through to `A' levels. I went to one such school. Twelve years in the same school must surely allow stronger bonds to develop than a six, four or two years stay in different schools. And it is not just bonds of friendship of students in the

Column: 1567

same year, but inter-generational as well. So should we review our systems and do those things which would allow Singaporeans themselves to develop such bonds?

    Sir, I said the sense of belonging to Singapore means doing things ourselves. It depends on each of us. And there are many things to do. If anyone is looking for ideas of what to get involved in, let me point out one - the support system for the elderly, in view of the ageing population. It is an area where Government has not got itself too deeply involved as yet. It is an excellent area to be left for those who want to see the development of a civil society.

    There are already some practising the spirit of civil society. They are the grassroots organisations, the unions, the co-operatives and the voluntary welfare organisations. There are many who sacrifice a lot of time to do things for the good of others. My definition of civil society may be different from others. Some think civil society excludes government or the establishment. I have no such qualms. I believe in getting things done, either by ourselves or with Government and the establishment. If it helps to get things done by working with Government, I see no objection to it. The satisfaction is in getting things done, not in the exclusion of Government.

    Rooting Singaporeans also means getting Singaporeans to feel that this is the land of opportunity. Some Singaporeans migrate because there are better or more exciting opportunities elsewhere. These are Singaporeans who apparently have the self-confidence to compete as foreign talent elsewhere. On the other hand, we have Singaporeans - mostly descendants of migrants or foreign talent - who object to foreign talent competing here. If we are to be a land of opportunity, we need the talent mass here for it to happen. So the vision of Singapore 21 means we Singaporeans developing the self-confidence to compete with foreign talent on our own turf, absorbing foreign talent, and moulding them into Singaporeans, and if not possible, pro-

Column: 1568

Singaporeans. It is this critical mass of talent that will enlarge that sphere of opportunity for our younger generation. If we are able to bring the best and brightest in the world like a magnet here, then our own will be able to compete with them and derive the satisfaction of competing with the best. Just as some of our top talent right now feel they want to compete with the world's best elsewhere. So I think it is for us to bring talent here to Singapore and not to exclude them.

    Having said this, I think, to me, it is quite clear that the Prime Minister is right. It will be a long road to S21, and we must persevere in this effort, for our good, for our children's good, and for our grandchildren.

    Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Bukit Timah)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to support the motion standing in the name of RAdm Teo Chee Hean and the Singapore 21 report presented by the Committee.

    As mentioned by Prime Minister Goh yesterday and many of my colleagues who spoke before me, the basic principle of this report is how to cultivate in our people the sense of loyalty towards our nation. That is on the basic foundation established by our first generation of leaders in Singapore. They have taken the decision to build up Singapore on this foundation. What decisions will the second generation leaders and the third generation leaders take?

    I think the most important reminder to us is the pledge that is being taken by our students every morning at the flag-raising ceremony. Although this pledge was worded by our first generation leaders some 30 years ago, it is still relevant to us now, and I believe it will continue to be relevant in the next century. The pledge reads: "We, the citizens of Singapore, pledge ourselves as one united people, regardless of race, language or religion, to build a democratic society based on justice and equality so as to achieve happiness, prosperity and progress for our nation."

Column: 1569



    I remember that at one political gathering, some people commented that the survival of Singapore was an accident in history. But if you look at our nation building and our survival, it can be said to be the result of a very important decision taken by our leaders. We live by this decision. We treasure this will to build up our nation. It is not the responsibility of just the Government but the responsibility of everybody. The second generation leaders and people, the third generation leaders and people, do they still maintain this will of survival? So when we are talking about a multi-racial, multi-religious and multi-lingual society, the feasible way is to be like in the past, to exercise tolerance, mutual respect, mutual understanding of one another's culture, to observe the festivals and the religious celebrations of the various races. Just like what the Prime Minister said yesterday and what my colleague, Minister Lim Boon Heng, and Mr Goh Choon Kang have said, we want to forge a common identity while maintaining diversity. This is something which is repeated over and over again in our Parliamentary debate. This is characteristic of Singapore. We can treat this as an advantage but it could also turn out to be a disadvantage to us. It depends on how we want to continue with our policy.

    Recently, we have many Parliamentarians from the Commonwealth countries coming to Singapore for the CPA meeting. I asked them what they felt was the characteristic in Singapore that they found to be most attractive. Almost everyone of them told me that the most attractive feature of Singapore is our multi-racial society. They were amazed that our people who are dressed in the Malay national dress, the Chinese or western dresses were happily chatting away at a common function together, using English as the common language. Yet, in the next minute, they would turn and speak in their own languages to people of their own community. It is simply fantastic!

    One expert who has been doing research on the history of the various

Column: 1570

countries remarked that he envied our bilingual policy. We are an amalgamation of the strong points of the various races. Singapore is one of the very few countries in the world where the people could have command of a first language and a second language which are of completely different backgrounds - our Chinese, English, Malay and Tamil. Other people consider this as some great assets to us. Then why do we want to give them up?

    The most important thing is that we must learn to forge a common identity while maintaining diversity. As what Prime Minister Goh has said, we must be able to communicate among ourselves in English and, at the same time, allow the various communities to maintain their traditional cultures and customs. And this is an advantage and a unique characteristic for our future survival. So in places where there are differences, we should have mutual tolerance and understanding.

    In the past 30 years, we have succeeded in maintaining harmony. I feel that in the future, we could still maintain this racial harmony. Now we have this S21 Report. Many people are asking why we need to discuss this Report. Have we not lived harmoniously all this while? But our leaders have very good foresight. They feel that even in this peaceful time, we have to be prepared for any crisis that may come in the future. We must learn how to overcome all the problems and challenges in our process of nation building.

    Under such major premises, I would like to deliberate on some details of the Report. In the last few days, we have been discussing how to make everyone identify with the nation. Because of the upgrading of their educational and skills level, and the globalisation of our economy, many people feel that they are now citizens of the whole world. This is inevitable. According to some preliminary survey, about 10% to 20% of our people have such a feeling. But the majority, the other 70% to 80% of our people, are busy hovering around the basic things in life. They want to have a stable job, a stable society, a pleasant living environment and a house

Column: 1571

or flat of their own, and have no problem in their daily needs. Perhaps, some people will ask: why are they not concerned with this S21 Vision? Why are they not participating in the discussion on this issue? It is not that they are not concerned. They are actually concerned with the matter. One elderly person told me that when we are on board a plane, our life is committed to the pilot. We would not ask the pilot whether he has been adequately trained, how many hours of flying time he has clocked, is he experienced, or is he confident that he would fly us all safely to our destination. We do not need to go into all that. So in our case, we have elected our leaders. They are the talented people. They have the ability to lead us. We are in good hands. It is not that we are not concerned. But we feel confident, because we have a good Government.

    I have contacted the People's Association and the Ministry of Education to find out what are the feelings of our people, the ordinary citizens of Singapore. Singaporeans are very busy. They are busy attending classes, training, busy with their family and a lot of things to do. And the People's Association reported to me that last year, for the RCs, the CCCs, the CCMCs, ie, the grassroots organisations, the participation rate was 7 million. Of course, many people participated in more than one event. On the average, our Residents Committees conduct some 200 to 300 activities in a year. The Sports Council told me that the participation rate was 1.2 million in their activities last year. The National Arts Council said its audience was about 700,000. Besides, we have the activities organised by NTUC, the welfare organisations and the religious organisations. I think we could easily gain an entry in the Guinness World of Records.

    I can safely say that Singapore is a nation where the people are actively participating in various community works. Just now Minister Lim has also mentioned that participation could be of different levels. How do we make them feel that their views and ideas are being reflected? As I said just now, we must recognise that there is a limitation in every country,

Column: 1572

particularly in our country, taking into consideration the environment around us. Under such circumstances, we need to elect some able people to lead us. It is not possible for the people to be directly involved in all activities.

    Our children, irrespective of their background, are assured of places in the school. Every child will have a place in a school. There is no one in Singapore who has to stop schooling because of financial difficulties. I believe that our political leaders can make such a promise. There is no one who has been denied medical treatment because of financial difficulties. There is no one who has no place, nowhere to go to, no place to stay in. I think if we conduct a thorough survey, we can be found to be quite a successful nation.

    With respect to religion, not many countries in the world can have a Sikh temple, Chinese temples, Catholic churches, mosques or Protestant churches, all within the radius of one kilometre, as in our Waterloo Street area.

    Someone told me a very interesting observation. She noticed that a good number of believers who had gone to worship at the Guan Yin Temple at Waterloo Street, passed by the Krishnan Temple next door, and spontaneously took out some money and dropped it into the donation box outside. This is a very special situation in Singapore where our people respect one another, and respect the religions of the other races.

    Just now I mentioned that in the schools, our students are actively participating in all the activities. How do we maintain such a practice? In a family, my Parliamentary colleagues have already deliberated on it. So I do not want to waste time repeating it. But I want to mention one point. Whenever we talk about the family, foreign talents, and an aging population, these are the key issues. We are Singaporeans and if we do not want foreign talents, how many babies have we had in Singapore? In the 70s, it was about 22 to 23 per thousand per year. In 1997, it was about 15 per thousand per

Column: 1573

year. According to a Japanese report on International Statistics, this figure will be dropping every year. The birth rate may drop to 12 per thousand per year. Can we find a way to break through? We always talk about solving this problem of an aging population. But have we given a thought to increasing our birth rate? Now that most women are working, can we encourage them to have more babies? So this is one area we need to look into. The mindset of our people is such that many people are thinking that they are citizens of the world. But the majority of our people are still identified with Singapore. Then, when we have foreign talents, how do we make them settle down in Singapore and merge into our society?

    The younger generation of Singaporeans must understand this. We have our limitations. We have to be sensitive of our environment and we are a small population. If we want to maintain our position as one of the top ten countries in the world in terms of economic development and standard of living, I think we must attract foreign talents and we must feel that everyone of us has a share and a part and role to play in our society.

    Another point I wish to raise is that just now, when we talked about participation and we said that we are a closely-knit society, one thing we can improve is that we may perhaps set up or establish a systematic "Emotion Contact Station". While we are all busy, very naturally, we take our interpersonal relationship for granted. Many voluntary workers told me that they have been volunteering for their whole life. People who have been donating blood for the past 20-30 years have enjoyed some priority when they go for medical treatment in the polyclinics or hospitals. When they reach the age of 60, their blood will not be accepted. So at 61, they cease to be blood-donors, and simultaneously all the special treatment previously given to them will be suspended. I would like to say that when we want to cultivate the spirit of care and concern, it is not only in the families but also in the community. Now all the

Column: 1574

schools are built by the Government. Our ordinary citizens can only participate in the school's management consultative committee. I think we should give the parents, and well-wishers, more roles to play in the management of the schools.

    Recently, a former Principal of the Chinese High School, Mr Cheng An Lun passed away. At his funeral, the Old Boys' Association and the School Board arranged for his hearse to pass through the school ground for the teachers and students to pay their last respects, and many people in the educational field are very touched by such an arrangement. It is a very touching show of respect and recognition for someone who has contributed enormously in the field of education during his lifetime.

    Now, the Government has rich financial resources. We could well afford to spend some money to recognise those who had contributed to our society in other fields, such as sports, arts, music, education, etc. Together with the clan associations, Old Boys' Associations and the other community organisations, we can show some form of respect, care and concern for former sportsmen, sportswomen, artists, musicians, etc. Recently, we read in the newspapers that some sportsmen who had in their heyday won honours for our nation, but in their old age, they lived in isolation and poverty with nobody to look after them. Perhaps the Sports Council could set up some sort of "Emotion Contact Station". In our society where everyone is very busy, where the economy is prosperous, we should systematically try to have some sort of communication with people who have contributed to our society in the past. We have spent a lot of time and effort to develop our economy. We encourage foreign investors to invest here and to create jobs for our people. However, as we have stable and strong reserves, we should seriously consider tying up our economic development with the development of our heartbeat.

    Perhaps, we should also put some of our local artworks or local songs on the Internet, so as to show to the world what

Column: 1575

we have. For example, it is very difficult to plant our national flower, the orchid. I have not conducted a survey. Perhaps the National Parks Board may think that it is too difficult to have orchids planted everywhere in Singapore. It is very difficult to make the orchid flower bloom, so it is easier to have some greenery instead. There is nothing wrong with it. But I think we should spend more effort and money on the propagation of our national flower. At least, have it on the Internet. With Singaporeans travelling to all places in the world, a look at our national flower on the Internet, will bring back fond memories f things back home.

    We have also to cultivate our arts bodies, like the dance groups and the various arts groups. We should spend more time and effort to cultivate them. If you go to the European countries, you will see a lot of these arts festivals, choral festivals, dance festivals, and what have you. When we have the "Sing Singapore" campaign, perhaps we could tie up with the CDC. As a matter of fact, on the 5th of June, the Bukit Timah CDC will have a "Singspiration" involving some 10,000 people.
